DataElement.preferredName: Follow-up Recurrence Death Survival Months Interval
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The survival interval in months is calculated using the month, day, and year of the Surv-Date DX Recode [1788] and the month, day, and year of the Surv-Date Active Followup [1782].

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Follow-up Recurrence Death Survival Month Interval
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The process by which information about the health status of an individual is obtained after a study has officially closed; an activity that continues something that has already begun or that repeats something that has already been done._To come back or to return._The cessation of life._Continuance of life or existence especially under adverse conditions; includes methods and philosophy of survival._One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks._The period of time or the distance separating two instances, events, or occurrences.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The process by which information about the health status of an individual is obtained after a study has officially closed.:To occur again.:The absence of life or state of being dead.

Concepts.definition: The process by which information about the health status of an individual is obtained after a study has officially closed; an activity that continues something that has already begun or that repeats something that has already been done.

Property.preferredDefinition: Continuance of life or existence especially under adverse conditions; includes methods and philosophy of survival.:One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.:The period of time or the distance separating two instances, events, or occurrences.

Concepts.definition: Continuance of life or existence especially under adverse conditions; includes methods and philosophy of survival.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
The period of time or the distance separating two instances, events, or occurrences.
